context: Hajj is the annual pilgrimage to Mecca and one of the Five Pillars of Islam. Every Muslim who is physically and financially capable must perform Hajj at least once in their lifetime.
Umrah is a pilgrimage to Mecca that can be undertaken at any time of the year. Unlike Hajj, Umrah is not obligatory but carries great spiritual rewards.
The rituals of Hajj include Ihram, Tawaf, Sa'i, standing at Arafat, Muzdalifah, and stoning the Jamarat. These rituals must be performed in order.
The rituals of Umrah include Ihram, Tawaf, and Sa'i between Safa and Marwah. Unlike Hajj, Umrah does not require standing at Arafat or stoning the Jamarat.
Ihram is a sacred state that Muslims enter to perform Hajj or Umrah. It includes specific spiritual practices and wearing special garments.
Tawaf is the act of circumambulating the Ka'aba seven times in a counterclockwise direction. It is a key ritual of both Hajj and Umrah.
Sa'i is the act of walking between the hills of Safa and Marwah seven times. It commemorates Hagar's search for water for her son, Ishmael.
Jamarat are three stone pillars in Mina that represent Satan. Pilgrims throw pebbles at them during Hajj to symbolize their rejection of evil.
Standing at Arafat is the most important ritual of Hajj. Pilgrims gather there to pray, repent, and seek forgiveness from Allah.
Muzdalifah is a place where pilgrims collect pebbles and pray after sunset on the day of Arafat. It is a significant part of the Hajj rituals.
